ROTATION-INVARIANT LOCAL RADIUS INDEX: A COMPACT TEXTURE SIMILARITY
FEATURE FOR CLASSIFICATION
Yuanhao Zhai, David L. Neuhoff
EECS Department, University of Michigan
ABSTRACT

This paper proposes a new rotation-invariant texture similar-
ity feature, called Rotation-Invariant Local Radius Index (RI-
LRI). Whereas the original LRI was designed for applications
that are sensitive to rotation and aimed to penalize rotation
monotonically, the new rotation-invariant LRI is well suited
to texture classiﬁcation. When combined with frequency do-
main contrast information and the well known Local Binary
Patterns (LBP) feature, the proposed metric has compara-
ble texture classiﬁcation accuracy to state-of-the-art metrics,
when tested on the Outex and CUReT databases. Moreover,
it has an approximately ten times lower dimensional feature
vector and requires substantially less computation than other
state-of-the-art texture features, such as those based on LBP.
Index Terms— LBP, LRI, Outex, CUReT
1. INTRODUCTION

Texture representation and modeling have been actively stud-
ied over the past few decades, due to its importance in many
research areas, including image processing, computer vision
and pattern recognition.
To fulﬁll the demands for differ-
ent applications, various similarity features and metrics have
been proposed to represent and classify texture patterns. For
problems like identical texture retrieval and perceptual image
compression, texture features and metrics should be insensi-
tive to spatial shifts, but penalize rotations monotonically [1].
Examples of such include Structural Texture Similarity Met-
rics (STSIM) [2–4] and Local Radius Index (LRI) [5]. Such
features and metrics have been successfully applied to a num-
ber of applications, e.g., the newly proposed perceptual image
compression algorithm Matched Texture Coding (MTC) [6].
However, for texture classiﬁcation, an active area of research,
rotation invariance is needed. In this paper we propose a mod-
iﬁcation of LRI that makes it rotation-invariant, while main-
taining its low complexity.
A common approach to texture classiﬁcation uses tex-
ture features and metrics, along with classiﬁcation algorithms
based on nearest neighbor search of a dictionary of labeled
texture patterns. For example, some methods are based on
co-occurrence matrices [7–9], which count the numbers of
pairs of pixels with various displacements and intensities. To
model textures with regular and repetitive patterns, Voronoi

tessellations [10, 11] and structural displacement rules [12–
14] are also used. Other well-known texture models are based
on Markov Random Fields [15, 16]. Besides spatial domain
analysis, many metrics have been developed in a transform
domain, including those based on Gabor ﬁlters [17, 18] and
steerable pyramid subband decompositions [2–4,19].
Recently, Local Binary Patterns (LBP) [20], proposed in
2002 as a new statistical texture feature, has drawn a lot of at-
tention. LBP is training-free and considers rotation-invariant
local neighborhood information.
It achieves good texture
classiﬁcation performance with relatively few computations
in the spatial domain. Subsequently, many additional texture
features have been motivated by LBP, such as Dominant LBP
(DLBP) [21] and Completed LBP (CLBP) [22]. In addition,
many complementary texture features have been combined
with LBP to attain better performance, including Dominant
Neighborhood Structure (DNS) [23], Enhanced Binary Cod-
ing (LEBC) [24], and LRI [5]. In this paper, a new texture
similarity feature for classiﬁcation, called rotation-invariant
LRI (RI-LRI), and corresponding similarity metrics are pro-
posed.
RI-LRI is developed based on the version of LRI
called LRI-A [5] and is complementary to LBP. As will be
shown in this paper, when combined with frequency domain
contrast information and LBP, the RI-LRI texture similarity
metric attains classiﬁcation performance comparable to state-
of-the-art metrics, when tested on the Outex and CUReT
databases. Moreover, the low dimensionality of LRI carries
over to RI-LRI, resulting in a method whose feature vector di-
mension is approximately ten times less than state-of-the-art
methods in [24] and requires substantially less computation.
The rest of the paper is organized as follows.
Sec. 2
reviews the recently proposed Local Radius Index (LRI).
Rotation-invariant LRI (RI-LRI) is proposed in Sec. 3.
In
Sec. 4, RI-LRI is combined with other texture features to
exploit their complementarity. Experiments and results are
discussed in Sec. 5, and Sec. 6 concludes the paper.
2. REVIEW OF LOCAL RADIUS INDEX (LRI)

LRI is a texture similarity feature designed for identical tex-
ture retrieval and image compression, where spatial shifts can
be tolerated but rotations and scalings should be penalized
monotonically. Two different types of LRI, namely LRI-A
and LRI-D, are described in [5]. In this paper, LRI-A is mod-

iﬁed so as to become rotation-invariant. The basic idea is
that LRI-A measures inter-edge distance distributions in dif-
ferent directions in the spatial domain, where inter-edge dis-
tance means the distance between two adjacent edges. Such
distributions provide good information about the sizes of tex-
ture elements in different directions. In particular, for each
pixel, the LRI-A operator generates eight integer directional
indices, each corresponding to one predeﬁned direction. Then
a histogram of the corresponding directional indices is com-
puted for each direction. The LRI-A feature vector for the
image is the collection of all eight histograms.
Speciﬁcally, as described in [5], for each pixel, consider
the eight directions corresponding to its eight nearest neigh-
bors. For each direction, the LRI-A operator produces an in-
teger index, depending on a threshold T and a size limit K.
In particular, for the ith pixel and direction d = 1, 2, . . . , 8,
the directional index Ii,d is computed as follows:

1. Ii,d = 0 if the absolute difference between the current
pixel and the adjacent one in direction d is less than T.
2. Ii,d = min{j, K} if j > 0 successive pixels in direc-
tion d are greater than the current pixel by at least T,
and the (j + 1)th pixel is not.
3. Ii,d = max{−j, −K} if j > 0 successive pixels in
direction d are smaller than the current pixel by at least
T, and the (j + 1)th pixel is not.

Note that Ii,d = 0 means pixel i is not adjacent to an edge
in direction d, whereas Ii,d ̸= 0 indicates the opposite. The
absolute value of an index indicates the size of the adjacent
texture element and its sign indicates whether the adjacent
edge is an increasing or decreasing one.
Of the two parameters involved in the LRI-A operator,
the threshold T determines what is considered an edge and
also controls noise sensitivity. As in [5], for homogeneous
textures, we choose T to equal the standard deviation of the
image divided by 2. The size limit K limits the maximum
size of texture elements that can be detected by LRI-A. As
suggested in [5], K = 4 is usually large enough.
As can be seen, the eight histograms for the image cap-
ture the inter-edge distance distributions in different direc-
tions. A texture similarity metric based on LRI-A feature vec-
tor could be derived by comparing the histogram similarity
using Kullback-Leibler Divergence [25]. However, these dis-
tributions are rotation sensitive. For example, if a texture pat-
tern is highly directional, then rotating the pattern will have a
rotational effect on the LRI-A features.
By combining the LRI metric with others based on com-
plementary features, namely LBP, Subband Contrast Distri-
bution (SCD) and Intensity Penalization (IP), the following
LRI+ metric was proposed in [5]:
LRI+ = LRIp1 × LBPp2 × f(1 −SCD)p3 × IP ,
where LRI+ is the metric value and f(x) = tan(x π

2 ). Param-
eters p1, p2, p3 weight the different features.

Note that in LRI+, the LBP feature is computed using
the surrounding eight pixels without interpolating to estimate
image values on a circle surrounding the current pixel. Ex-
perimental results showed that this approximation does not
inﬂuence overall classiﬁcation accuracy. Note also that, as
described in [5], simple pixel difference ﬁltering in four di-
rections enables the LRI feature to be computed with only 4K
operations per pixel (opp), approximately. It also enables the
other components of LRI+ (LBP, SCD, IP) to be determined
with few additional computations.
3. ROTATION-INVARIANT LRI (RI-LRI)

As mentioned earlier, for texture classiﬁcation, rotation-
invariance is desired. To make a rotation-invariant version of
LRI, we propose to estimate a dominant direction for each
pixel based on the eight LRI-A directional indices, and then
rotate the indices so the dominant direction points to some
pre-speciﬁed direction. In particular, the dominant direction

together with their dominant directions and the RI-LRI in-

achieve rotation-invariance. As the edge rotates, the RI-LRI
indices (the numbers below each ﬁgure) remain unchanged.
By comparing (a) and (d), we can see that on both sides of
an edge, pixels have the same dominant direction pointing to
the larger intensity. However, their RI-LRI indices are differ-
ent because of their different neighborhoods. Part (e) shows
a pixel in a transition region. Still, the dominant direction
points to the larger intensity. One thing to mention is that if
in the deﬁnition of Di, |Ii,d| is used instead of Ii,d, a pixel
in such transition regions will not have a dominant direction
pointing to the larger intensity. Parts (f), (g) and (h) present
three sample pixels near corners. One can easily see the dis-
tinctive power of RI-LRI indices by comparing (f) and (g).

As with LRI, for each pixel, the RI-LRI operator outputs
eight integer indices, each for one direction. As we found
from experiments, most of the distinctive information is con-
tained in the dominant direction, the opposite direction, and
the two orthogonal directions. In addition, the two orthog-
onal directions contain correlated information, which can be
beneﬁcially exploited using a two-dimensional histogram. To
be concrete, starting with the dominant direction and moving
counter clockwise, we label the directions as 1, 2, . . . , 8. We
claim that most of the information is included in directions
1,3,5 and 7. Moreover, orthogonal directions 1 and 3 contain
correlated information, as do orthogonal directions 5 and 7.

With this in mind, the RI-LRI feature vector consists of
one two-dimensional histogram. Speciﬁcally, for each pair
(m, n) of integers between −K and K, we count the number
of pixels i such that (RIi,1, RIi,3) = (m, n) and add to it the
number of pixels i such that (RIi,5, RIi,7) = (m, n). The
collection of such sums, C(m, n), −K ≤m, n ≤K, com-
prises the two-dimensional histogram that is the RI-LRI fea-
ture vector of length (2K + 1)2. A texture similarity met-
ric is then formed by computing the Kullback-Leibler diver-
gence [25] between the histograms of the two images to be
compared.

Using the same difference ﬁltering used for LRI, the RI-
LRI feature vector can be computed with only 8K + 15 opp,
approximately. Table 1 shows the complexities of RI-LRI and
LBP with various parameters. One can see that RI-LRI is
simpler than the simplest version of LBP with interpolation.

4. RI-LRI BASED TEXTURE SIMILARITY METRIC

As mentioned earlier, the metric LRI+ [5] was proposed as
a combination of LRI, LBP [20], SCD and IP. LRI and LBP
are complementary in that they represent local information
in radial and tangent directions, respectively. SCD measures
subband contrast distribution. IP is an optional feature penal-
izing large intensity shifts. Here, we adopt a similar approach
to the design of a rotation invariant metric.
In texture classiﬁcation, one generally wants a metric that
is intensity-invariant, as well as rotation-invariant.
Hence,
the IP term in LRI+ is excluded from RI-LRI+. However,
subband contrast distribution can still play an important role.
Since the original rotation-variant SCD cannot be used, we
propose a rotation-invariant version of SCD, called SCDri.
4.1. Rotation-invariant Subband Contrast Distribution

Motivated by LEBC [24], we use the edge (ﬁrst deriva-
tive) and bar (second derivative) ﬁlters from the Root Fil-
ter Set (RFS) [26, 27].
In this work, we set the num-
ber of ﬁlter orientations to be eight and use three scales
(σx, σy) = {(1, 3), (2, 6), (4, 12)}, for a total of 48 ﬁlters, as
shown in Figure 2. We normalize the texture image to have
unit variance and then ﬁlter the image using these 48 ﬁlters.
The normalization gives invariance to global afﬁne illumina-
tion changes [24]. At each scale, eight subband variances are
computed. To achieve rotation-invariance, for each scale, sort
the eight directional subband variances in descending order.
As a result, we end up with a 48-dimensional feature vector
S = {s1, s2, . . . , s48} that is piecewise monotonic.
For two images x and y, with feature vectors Sx and Sy,
the similarity score is

where c is a small constant to increase robustness and avoid

The SCDri(x, y) values lie between 0 and 1,
with 1 meaning identical. By multiplicatively combining all
48 terms, we use the hypothesis that similar texture patterns
should have similar variances in all 48 subbands.
4.2. Proposed texture similarity metric: RI-LRI+

As in [5], we propose the following way to combine RI-LRI
with LBP and SCDri to obtain a better metric:
RI-LRI+ = RI-LRIp1 × LBPp2 × (1 −SCDri)p3 .

Parameters p1, p2 and p3 weight the different features. RI-
LRI+ values are non-negative, with 0 meaning identical and

5. EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS

This section reports test results of RI-LRI and RI-LRI+ using
the Outex [28] and CUReT databases [29]. The newly pro-
posed metrics are compared to state-of-the-art metric, LEBC
[24], and other recently proposed metrics, including DLBP
[21], CLBP [22], DNS [23], VZ-MR8 [26] and VZ-Joint [27].
5.1. Experiment 1: Outex database

To make a fair comparison with previous methods, experi-
ments are performed in the same way as in [20–24], which
use two test suites in the Outex database [28]: TC10 and
TC12. Each test suite contains 24 texture classes obtained
under three illumination conditions (“horizon”,“inca” and
“t184”) and nine orientations (0 ◦, 5 ◦, 10 ◦, 15 ◦, 30 ◦, 45 ◦,
60 ◦, 75 ◦and 90 ◦). For each texture class, under each illu-
mination and rotation condition, there are 20 non-overlapped
128 × 128 texture samples. The experiment is based on a
nearest neighbor classiﬁer with a “dictionary” composed of
TC10 “inca” images with orientation 0◦. Three classiﬁcation
results are reported based on different testing images, namely
the remaining “inca” samples in TC10, “t184” and “horizon”
samples in TC12.
Metric performance is measured by classiﬁcation accu-
racy.
Table 2 shows experimental results for our methods
based on our experiments, as well as for other methods based
on performance reported in [20–24]. The ﬁrst two lines show

and RI-LRI with K = 4, which
are the two simplest and the most basic metrics. The results
show that although RI-LRI is computationally more efﬁcient,
its classiﬁcation accuracy signiﬁcantly outperforms LBP. Be-
cause of its simplicity, RI-LRI could be added to existing or
future texture similarity metrics without increasing complex-
ity. Starting from the third line, the results of more sophis-
ticated metrics are shown, with LEBC and RI-LRI+ being
the best. While LEBC appears to have slightly better perfor-
mance than RI-LRI+, its 1280-dimensional feature vector is
much larger than the 139-dimensional RI-LRI+ feature vec-
tor, resulting in much higher computational complexity.
5.2. Experiment 2: CUReT database

The CUReT database [29] contains 61 texture classes, each
with 92 images obtained from different viewpoints and illu-
mination conditions (5612 images in total). Following the

When feature dimension is considered, the 139-dimensional

the 960-dimensional VZ-MR8 feature vector and the 1280-
dimensional LEBC feature vector. In short, the proposed RI-
LRI+ has comparable performance with the state-of-art met-
ric, LEBC, with a much lower dimensional feature vector, and
correspondingly less complexity.
6. CONCLUSIONS

This paper proposes a new rotation-invariant texture similar-
ity feature, called RI-LRI, which is developed from the re-
cently proposed LRI. When combined with LBP and SCDri,
the proposed metric, RI-LRI+, has comparable texture clas-
siﬁcation accuracy to the state-of-the-art metrics, when tested
on the Outex and the CUReT databases. It has a much lower
dimensional feature vector and requires substantially less
computation than other state-of-the-art texture features, such
as those based on LBP. Moreover, with Occam’s razor in
mind, the lower dimensionality may itself be an indicator of
saliency.
